section.name: Installation of the programming environment.
section.p:
I recommend Debian Scretch (9) with LXDE interface. There is its 32bit version. To install OpenJDK on Debian based linux just run as "root" "apt-get install openjdk-8-jdk" or "sudo apt-get install openjdk-8-jdk". On Red Hat based Linux run "dnf install java-1.8.0-openjdk-devel". Then set environment variables in the .bashrc file, for Debian example:
export ANT_HOME=$HOME/programmer/java/apache-ant-1.10.6 export CATALINA_HOME=$HOME/programmer/java/apache-tomcat-7.0.82 export TOMCATA_HOME=$HOME/programmer/java/apache-tomcat-7.0.68a export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64 export H2DRIVERS=$HOME/.m2/repository/org/postgresql/postgresql/9.4-1206-jdbc4/postgresql-9.4-1206-jdbc4.jar:$HOME/.m2/repository/org/xerial/sqlite-jdbc/3.21.0.1/sqlite-jdbc-3.21.0.1.jar:$HOME/.m2/repository/mysql/mysql-connector-java/5.1.40/mysql-connector-java-5.1.40.jar export ANDROID_HOME=$HOME/Android/Sdk export PATH=$PATH:$HOME/programmer/java/apache-maven-3.5.2/bin:$ANT_HOME/bin:$ANDROID_HOME/platform-tools:$ANDROID_HOME/tools export GPG_TTY=$(tty)
* you will create folders that is described in the environment variables, and maven artifacts will be downloaded in farther steps.
You can use OpenJDK included in "Android IDE Studio". You need Android IDE Studio to make Android version. You should install it first.
Just create folder e.g. "$HOME/programmer/java/" for Unix like OS, or "C:\programmer\java" for MS Windows. Then download apache-maven-3.5.2.zip and unpack it there.
section.h4: Make environment variables in MS Windows
section.p:
On MS Windows 10 open "Search" and type "env" then "Edit the system environment variables" will be listed, so choose it, "System Properties" window will be appeared, switch to "Advanced" then push "Environment variables", then add or change:
Set JAVA_HOME to standard location C:\Program Files\Android\Android Studio\jre (check it out)
ANDROID_HOME - in Android Studion open SDK manager to see Android SDK Location
Path - leave all entries and add
After saving, check it: open Power Shell and type "$env:JAVA_HOME" or "$env:Path"
